1	She possessed an art that sufficed [CM] even in a land that afforded comparatively little scope for its exercise [CM] to supply food for her thriving infant and herself [P] It was the art then [CM] as now [CM] almost the only one within a woman s grasp of needlework [P] She bore on her breast [CM] in the curiously embroidered letter [CM] a specimen of her delicate and imaginative skill [CM] of which the dames of a court might gladly have availed themselves [CM] to add the richer and more spiritual adornment of human ingenuity to their fabrics of silk and gold [P] Here [CM] indeed [CM] in the sable simplicity that generally characterized the Puritanic modes of dress [CM] there might be an infrequent call for the finer productions of her handiwork [P] Yet the taste of the age [CM] demanding whatever was elaborate in compositions of this kind [CM] did not fail to extend its influence over our stern progenitors [CM] who had cast behind them so many fashions which it might seem harder to dispense with [P] Public ceremonies [CM] such as ordinations [CM] the installation of magistrates [CM] and all that could give majesty to the forms in which a new government manifested itself to the people [CM] were [CM] as a matter of policy [CM] marked by a stately and well [D] conducted ceremonial [CM] and a sombre [CM] but yet a studied magnificence [P] Deep ruffs [CM] painfully wrought bands [CM] and gorgeously embroidered gloves [CM] were all deemed necessary to the official state of men assuming the reins of power [S] and were readily allowed to individuals dignified by rank or wealth [CM] even while sumptuary laws forbade these and similar extravagances to the plebeian order [P] In the array of funerals [CM] too [CM] whether for the apparel of the dead body [CM] or to typify [CM] by manifold emblematic devices of sable cloth and snowy lawn [CM] the sorrow of the survivors [CM] there was a frequent and characteristic demand for such labor as Hester Prynne could supply [P] Baby [D] linen for babies then wore robes of state afforded still another possibility of toil and emolument [P] [PB] By degrees [CM] nor very slowly [CM] her handiwork became what would now be termed the fashion

1	He was not much acquainted with valves of any sort [CM] but he knew that valvae were folding [D] doors [CM] and through this crevice came a sudden light startling him with his first vivid notion of finely adjusted mechanism in the human frame [P] A liberal education had of course left him free to read the indecent passages in the school classics [CM] but beyond a general sense of secrecy and obscenity in connection with his internal structure [CM] had left his imagination quite unbiassed [CM] so that for anything he knew his brains lay in small bags at his temples [CM] and he had no more thought of representing to himself how his blood circulated than how paper served instead of gold [P] But the moment of vocation had come [CM] and before he got down from his chair [CM] the world was made new to him by a presentiment of endless processes filling the vast spaces planked out of his sight by that wordy ignorance which he had supposed to be knowledge [P] From that hour Lydgate felt the growth of an intellectual passion [P] [PB] We are not afraid of telling over and over again how a man comes to fall in love with a woman and be wedded to her [CM] or else be fatally parted from her [P] Is it due to excess of poetry or of stupidity that we are never weary of describing what King James called a woman s makdom and her fairnesse [CM] never weary of listening to the twanging of the old Troubadour strings [CM] and are comparatively uninterested in that other kind of makdom and fairnesse which must be wooed with industrious thought and patient renunciation of small desires [QN] In the story of this passion [CM] too [CM] the development varies [CN] sometimes it is the glorious marriage [CM] sometimes frustration and final parting [P] And not seldom the catastrophe is bound up with the other passion [CM] sung by the Troubadours [P] For in the multitude of middle [D] aged men who go about their vocations in a daily course determined for them much in the same way as the tie of their cravats [CM] there is always a good number who once meant to shape their own deeds and alter the world a little
1	shod but merry children [P] [PB] Dorothea by this time had looked deep into the ungauged reservoir of Mr [P] Casaubon s mind [CM] seeing reflected there in vague labyrinthine extension every quality she herself brought [S] had opened much of her own experience to him [CM] and had understood from him the scope of his great work [CM] also of attractively labyrinthine extent [P] For he had been as instructive as Milton s affable archangel [S] and with something of the archangelic manner he told her how he had undertaken to show what indeed had been attempted before [CM] but not with that thoroughness [CM] justice of comparison [CM] and effectiveness of arrangement at which Mr [P] Casaubon aimed that all the mythical systems or erratic mythical fragments in the world were corruptions of a tradition originally revealed [P] Having once mastered the true position and taken a firm footing there [CM] the vast field of mythical constructions became intelligible [CM] nay [CM] luminous with the reflected light of correspondences [P] But to gather in this great harvest of truth was no light or speedy work [P] His notes already made a formidable range of volumes [CM] but the crowning task would be to condense these voluminous still [D] accumulating results and bring them [CM] like the earlier vintage of Hippocratic books [CM] to fit a little shelf [P] In explaining this to Dorothea [CM] Mr [P] Casaubon expressed himself nearly as he would have done to a fellow [D] student [CM] for he had not two styles of talking at command [CN] it is true that when he used a Greek or Latin phrase he always gave the English with scrupulous care [CM] but he would probably have done this in any case [P] A learned provincial clergyman is accustomed to think of his acquaintances as of lords [CM] knyghtes [CM] and other noble and worthi men [CM] that conne Latyn but lytille [P] [PB] Dorothea was altogether captivated by the wide embrace of this conception [P] Here was something beyond the shallows of ladies school literature [CN] here was a living Bossuet [CM] whose work would reconcile complete knowledge with devoted piety [S] here was a modern Augustine who united the glories of doctor and saint

knew Mr [P] Tyke [CM] and even then I should require to know the cases in which he was applied [P] Lydgate smiled [CM] but he was bent on being circumspect [P] [PB] Of course you cannot enter fully into the merits of this measure at present [P] But here Mr [P] Bulstrode began to speak with a more chiselled emphasis the subject is likely to be referred to the medical board of the infirmary [CM] and what I trust I may ask of you is [CM] that in virtue of the cooperation between us which I now look forward to [CM] you will not [CM] so far as you are concerned [CM] be influenced by my opponents in this matter [P] [PB] I hope I shall have nothing to do with clerical disputes [CM] said Lydgate [P] The path I have chosen is to work well in my own profession [P] [PB] My responsibility [CM] Mr [P] Lydgate [CM] is of a broader kind [P] With me [CM] indeed [CM] this question is one of sacred accountableness [S] whereas with my opponents [CM] I have good reason to say that it is an occasion for gratifying a spirit of worldly opposition [P] But I shall not therefore drop one iota of my convictions [CM] or cease to identify myself with that truth which an evil generation hates [P] I have 1	And this [CM] moreover [CM] was a mother s estimate of the child s disposition [P] Any other observer might have seen few but unamiable traits [CM] and have given them a far darker coloring [P] But now the idea came strongly into Hester s mind [CM] that Pearl [CM] with her remarkable precocity and acuteness [CM] might already have approached the age when she could be made a friend [CM] and intrusted with as much of her mother s sorrows as could be imparted [CM] without irreverence either to the parent or the child [P] In the little chaos of Pearl s character there might be seen emerging and could have been [CM] from the very first the steadfast principles of an unflinching courage [CM] an uncontrollable will [CM] a sturdy pride [CM] which might be disciplined into self [D] respect [CM] and a bitter scorn of many things [CM] which [CM] when examined [CM] might be found to have the taint of falsehood in them [P] She possessed affections [CM] too [CM] though hitherto acrid and disagreeable [CM] as are the richest flavors of unripe fruit [P] With all these sterling attributes [CM] thought Hester [CM] the evil which she inherited from her mother must be great indeed [CM] if a noble woman do not grow out of this elfish child [P] [PB] Pearl s inevitable tendency to hover about the enigma of the scarlet letter seemed an innate quality of her being [P] From the earliest epoch of her conscious life [CM] she had entered upon this as her appointed mission [P] Hester had often fancied that Providence had a design of justice and retribution [CM] in endowing the child with this marked propensity [S] but never [CM] until now [CM] had she bethought herself to ask [CM] whether [CM] linked with that design [CM] there might not likewise be a purpose of mercy and beneficence [P] heart [CM] and converted it into a tomb [QN] and to help her to overcome the passion [CM] once so wild [CM] and even yet neither dead nor asleep [CM] but only imprisoned within the same tomb

1	for Miss Brooke s plain dressing was due to mixed conditions [CM] in most of which her sister shared [P] The pride of being ladies had something to do with it [CN] the Brooke connections [CM] though not exactly aristocratic [CM] were unquestionably good [CN] if you inquired backward for a generation or two [CM] you would not find any yard [D] measuring or parcel [D] tying forefathers anything lower than an admiral or a clergyman [S] and there was even an ancestor discernible as a Puritan gentleman who served under Cromwell [CM] but afterwards conformed [CM] and managed to come out of all political troubles as the proprietor of a respectable family estate [P] Young women of such birth [CM] living in a quiet country [D] house [CM] and attending a village church hardly larger than a parlor [CM] naturally regarded frippery as the ambition of a huckster s daughter [P] Then there was well [D] bred economy [CM] which in those days made show in dress the first item to be deducted from [CM] when any margin was required for expenses more distinctive of rank [P] Such reasons would have been enough to account for plain dress [CM] quite apart from religious feeling [S] but in Miss Brooke s case [CM] religion alone would have determined it [S] and Celia mildly acquiesced in all her sister s sentiments [CM] only infusing them with that common [D] sense which is able to accept momentous doctrines without any eccentric agitation [P] Dorothea knew many passages of Pascal s Pensees and of Jeremy Taylor by heart [S] and to her the destinies of mankind [CM] seen by the light of Christianity [CM] made the solicitudes of feminine fashion appear an occupation for Bedlam [P] She could not reconcile the anxieties of a spiritual life involving eternal consequences [CM] with a keen interest in gimp and artificial protrusions of drapery [P] Her mind was theoretic [CM] and yearned by its nature after some lofty conception of the world which might frankly include the parish of Tipton and her own rule of conduct there [S] she was enamoured of intensity and greatness [CM] and rash in embracing whatever seemed to her to have those aspects [S] likely to seek martyrdom [CM] to make retractations [CM] and then to incur martyrdom after all in a quarter where she had not sought it

[Illustration] [PB] IV [P] [PB] THE INTERVIEW [P] [PB] After her return to the prison [CM] Hester Prynne was found to be in a state of nervous excitement that demanded constant watchfulness [CM] lest she should perpetrate violence on herself [CM] or do some half [D] frenzied mischief to the poor babe [P] As night approached [CM] it proving impossible to quell her insubordination by rebuke or threats of punishment [CM] Master Brackett [CM] the jailer [CM] thought fit to introduce a physician [P] He described him as a man of skill in all Christian modes of physical science [CM] and likewise familiar with whatever the savage people could teach [CM] in respect to medicinal herbs and roots that grew in the forest [P] To say the truth [CM] there was much need of professional assistance [CM] not merely for Hester herself [CM] but still more urgently for the child [S] who [CM] drawing its sustenance from the maternal bosom [CM] seemed to have drank in with it all the turmoil [CM] the anguish and despair [CM] which pervaded the mother s system [P] It now writhed in convulsions of pain [CM] and was a forcible type [CM] in its little frame [CM] of the moral agony which Hester Prynne had borne throughout the day [P] [PB] Closely following the jailer into the dismal apartment appeared that individual [CM] of singular aspect [CM] whose presence in the crowd had been of such deep interest to the wearer of the scarlet letter [P] He was lodged in the prison [CM] not as suspected of any offence [CM] but as the most convenient and suitable mode of disposing of him [CM] until the magistrates should have conferred with the Indian sagamores respecting his ransom [P] His name was announced as Roger Chillingworth [P] The jailer [CM] after ushering him into the room [CM] remained a moment [CM] marvelling at the comparative quiet that followed his entrance [S] for Hester Prynne had immediately become as still as death [CM] although the child continued to moan

1	On weekends his Rolls [D] Royce became an omnibus [CM] bearing parties to and from the city between nine in the morning and long past midnight [CM] while his station wagon scampered like a brisk yellow bug to meet all trains [P] And on Mondays eight servants [CM] including an extra gardener [CM] toiled all day with mops and scrubbing [D] brushes and hammers and garden [D] shears [CM] repairing the ravages of the night before [P] [PB] Every Friday five crates of oranges and lemons arrived from a fruiterer in New York every Monday these same oranges and lemons left his back door in a pyramid of pulpless halves [P] There was a machine in the kitchen which could extract the juice of two hundred oranges in half an hour if a little button was pressed two hundred times by a butler s thumb [P] [PB] At least once a fortnight a corps of caterers came down with several hundred feet of canvas and enough coloured lights to make a Christmas tree of Gatsby s enormous garden [P] On buffet tables [CM] garnished with glistening hors [D] d oeuvre [CM] spiced baked hams crowded against salads of harlequin designs and pastry pigs and turkeys bewitched to a dark gold [P] In the main hall a bar with a real brass rail was set up [CM] and stocked with gins and liquors and with cordials so long forgotten that most of his female guests were too young to know one from another [P] [PB] By seven o clock the orchestra has arrived [CM] no thin five [D] piece affair [CM] but a whole pitful of oboes and trombones and saxophones and viols and cornets and piccolos [CM] and low and high drums [P] The last swimmers have come in from the beach now and are dressing upstairs [S] the cars from New York are parked five deep in the drive [CM] and already the halls and salons and verandas are gaudy with primary colours [CM] and hair bobbed in strange new ways [CM] and shawls beyond the dreams of Castile [P] The bar is in full swing [CM] and floating rounds of cocktails permeate the garden outside [CM] until the air is alive with chatter and laughter [CM] and casual innuendo and introductions forgotten on the spot [CM] and enthusiastic meetings between women who never knew each other s names

1	Hester Prynne imbibed this spirit [P] She assumed a freedom of speculation [CM] then common enough on the other side of the Atlantic [CM] but which our forefathers [CM] had they known it [CM] would have held to be a deadlier crime than that stigmatized by the scarlet letter [P] In her lonesome cottage [CM] by the sea [D] shore [CM] thoughts visited her [CM] such as dared to enter no other dwelling in New England [S] shadowy guests [CM] that would have been as perilous as demons to their entertainer [CM] could they have been seen so much as knocking at her door [P] [PB] It is remarkable [CM] that persons who speculate the most boldly often conform with the most perfect quietude to the external regulations of society [P] The thought suffices them [CM] without investing itself in the flesh and blood of action [P] So it seemed to be with Hester [P] Yet [CM] had little Pearl never come to her from the spiritual world [CM] it might have been far otherwise [P] Then [CM] she might have come down to us in history [CM] hand in hand with Ann Hutchinson [CM] as the foundress of a religious sect [P] She might [CM] in one of her phases [CM] have been a prophetess [P] She might [CM] and not improbably would [CM] have suffered death from the stern tribunals of the period [CM] for attempting to undermine the foundations of the Puritan establishment [P] But [CM] in the education of her child [CM] the mother s enthusiasm of thought had something to wreak itself upon [P] Providence [CM] in the person of this little girl [CM] had assigned to Hester s charge the germ and blossom of womanhood [CM] to be cherished and developed amid a host of difficulties [P] Everything was against her [P] The world was hostile [P] The child s own nature had something wrong in it [CM] which continually betokened that she had been born amiss [CM] the effluence of her mother s lawless passion [CM] and often impelled Hester to ask [CM] in bitterness of heart [CM] whether it were for ill or good that the poor little creature had been born at all [P] [PB] Indeed [CM] the same dark question often rose into her mind [CM] with reference to the whole race of womanhood

1	creative spirit [CM] and communicated itself to a thousand objects [CM] as a torch kindles a flame wherever it may be applied [P] The unlikeliest materials a stick [CM] a bunch of rags [CM] a flower were the puppets of Pearl s witchcraft [CM] and [CM] without undergoing any outward change [CM] became spiritually adapted to whatever drama occupied the stage of her inner world [P] Her one baby [D] voice served a multitude of imaginary personages [CM] old and young [CM] to talk withal [P] The pine [D] trees [CM] aged [CM] black and solemn [CM] and flinging groans and other melancholy utterances on the breeze [CM] needed little transformation to figure as Puritan elders [S] the ugliest weeds of the garden were their children [CM] whom Pearl smote down and uprooted [CM] most unmercifully [P] It was wonderful [CM] the vast variety of forms into which she threw her intellect [CM] with no continuity [CM] indeed [CM] but darting up and dancing [CM] always in a state of preternatural activity [CM] soon sinking down [CM] as if exhausted by so rapid and feverish a tide of life [CM] and succeeded by other shapes of a similar wild energy [P] It was like nothing so much as the phantasmagoric play of the northern lights [P] In the mere exercise of the fancy [CM] however [CM] and the sportiveness of a growing mind [CM] there might be little more than was observable in other children of bright faculties [S] except as Pearl [CM] in the dearth of human playmates [CM] was thrown more upon the visionary throng which she created [P] The singularity lay in the hostile feelings with which the child regarded all these offspring of her own heart and mind [P] She never created a friend [CM] but seemed always to be sowing broadcast the dragon s teeth [CM] whence sprung a harvest of armed enemies [CM] against whom she rushed to battle [P] It was inexpressibly sad then what depth of sorrow to a mother [CM] who felt in her own heart the cause [E] to observe [CM] in one so young [CM] this constant recognition of an adverse world [CM] and so fierce a training of the energies that were to make good her cause [CM] in the contest that must ensue

[CM] began to stretch out beside us and twinkle against the windows [CM] and the dim lights of small Wisconsin stations moved by [CM] a sharp wild brace came suddenly into the air [P] We drew in deep breaths of it as we walked back from dinner through the cold vestibules [CM] unutterably aware of our identity with this country for one strange hour [CM] before we melted indistinguishably into it again [P] [PB] That s my Middle West not the wheat or the prairies or the lost Swede towns [CM] but the thrilling returning trains of my youth [CM] and the street lamps and sleigh bells in the frosty dark and the shadows of holly wreaths thrown by lighted windows on the snow [P] I am part of that [CM] a little solemn with the feel of those long winters [CM] a little complacent from growing up in the Carraway house in a city where dwellings are still called through decades by a family s name [P] I see now that this has been a story of the West [CM] after all Tom and Gatsby [CM] Daisy and Jordan and I [CM] were all Westerners [CM] and perhaps we possessed some deficiency in common which made us subtly unadaptable to Eastern life [P] [PB] Even when the East excited me most [CM] even when I was most keenly aware of its superiority to the bored [CM] sprawling [CM] swollen towns beyond the Ohio [CM] with their interminable inquisitions which spared only the children and the very old even then it had always for me a quality of distortion

1	So magnificent was the small figure [CM] when thus arrayed [CM] and such was the splendor of Pearl s own proper beauty [CM] shining through the gorgeous robes which might have extinguished a paler loveliness [CM] that there was an absolute circle of radiance around her [CM] on the darksome cottage floor [P] And yet a russet gown [CM] torn and soiled with the child s rude play [CM] made a picture of her just as perfect [P] Pearl s aspect was imbued with a spell of infinite variety [S] in this one child there were many children [CM] comprehending the full scope between the wild [D] flower prettiness of a peasant [D] baby [CM] and the pomp [CM] in little [CM] of an infant princess [P] Throughout all [CM] however [CM] there was a trait of passion [CM] a certain depth of hue [CM] which she never lost [S] and if [CM] in any of her changes [CM] she had grown fainter or paler [CM] she would have ceased to be herself [CM] it would have been no longer Pearl [E] [PB] This outward mutability indicated [CM] and did not more than fairly express [CM] the various properties of her inner life [P] Her nature appeared to possess depth [CM] too [CM] as well as variety [S] but or else Hester s fears deceived her it lacked reference and adaptation to the world into which she was born [P] The child could not be made amenable to rules [P] In giving her existence [CM] a great law had been broken [S] and the result was a being whose elements were perhaps beautiful and brilliant [CM] but all in disorder [S] or with an order peculiar to themselves [CM] amidst which the point of variety and arrangement was difficult or impossible to be discovered [P] Hester could only account for the child s character and even then most vaguely and imperfectly by recalling what she herself had been [CM] during that momentous period while Pearl was imbibing her soul from the spiritual world [CM] and her bodily frame from its material of earth [P] The mother s impassioned state had been the medium through which were transmitted to the unborn infant the rays of its moral life

1	Dimmesdale [P] The young divine [CM] whose scholar [D] like renown still lived in Oxford [CM] was considered by his more fervent admirers as little less than a heaven [D] ordained apostle [CM] destined [CM] should he live and labor for the ordinary term of life [CM] to do as great deeds for the now feeble New England Church [CM] as the early Fathers had achieved for the infancy of the Christian faith [P] About this period [CM] however [CM] the health of Mr [P] Dimmesdale had evidently begun to fail [P] By those best acquainted with his habits [CM] the paleness of the young minister s cheek was accounted for by his too earnest devotion to study [CM] his scrupulous fulfilment of parochial duty [CM] and [CM] more than all [CM] by the fasts and vigils of which he made a frequent practice [CM] in order to keep the grossness of this earthly state from clogging and obscuring his spiritual lamp [P] Some declared [CM] that [CM] if Mr [P] Dimmesdale were really going to die [CM] it was cause enough [CM] that the world was not worthy to be any longer trodden by his feet [P] He himself [CM] on the other hand [CM] with characteristic humility [CM] avowed his belief [CM] that [CM] if Providence should see fit to remove him [CM] it would be because of his own unworthiness to perform its humblest mission here on earth [P] With all this difference of opinion as to the cause of his decline [CM] there could be no question of the fact [P] His form grew emaciated [S] his voice [CM] though still rich and sweet [CM] had a certain melancholy prophecy of decay in it [S] he was often observed [CM] on any slight alarm or other sudden accident [CM] to put his hand over his heart [CM] with first a flush and then a paleness [CM] indicative of pain [P] [PB] Such was the young clergyman s condition [CM] and so imminent the prospect that his dawning light would be extinguished [CM] all untimely [CM] when Roger Chillingworth made his advent to the town [P] His first entry on the scene [CM] few people could tell whence [CM] dropping down [CM] as it were [CM] out of the sky [CM] or starting from the nether earth [CM] had an aspect of mystery [CM] which was easily heightened to the miraculous

1	I [P] [PB] THE PRISON [D] DOOR [P] [PB] [Illustration] [PB] A throng of bearded men [CM] in sad [D] colored garments [CM] and gray [CM] steeple [D] crowned hats [CM] intermixed with women [CM] some wearing hoods and others bareheaded [CM] was assembled in front of a wooden edifice [CM] the door of which was heavily timbered with oak [CM] and studded with iron spikes [P] [PB] The founders of a new colony [CM] whatever Utopia of human virtue and happiness they might originally project [CM] have invariably recognized it among their earliest practical necessities to allot a portion of the virgin soil as a cemetery [CM] and another portion as the site of a prison [P] In accordance with this rule [CM] it may safely be assumed that the forefathers of Boston had built the first prison [D] house somewhere in the vicinity of Cornhill [CM] almost as seasonably as they marked out the first burial [D] ground [CM] on Isaac Johnson s lot [CM] and round about his grave [CM] which subsequently became the nucleus of all the congregated sepulchres in the old churchyard of King s Chapel [P] Certain it is [CM] that [CM] some fifteen or twenty years after the settlement of the town [CM] the wooden jail was already marked with weather [D] stains and other indications of age [CM] which gave a yet darker aspect to its beetle [D] browed and gloomy front [P] The rust on the ponderous iron [D] work of its oaken door looked more antique than anything else in the New World [P] Like all that pertains to crime [CM] it seemed never to have known a youthful era [P] Before this ugly edifice [CM] and between it and the wheel [D] track of the street [CM] was a grass [D] plot [CM] much overgrown with burdock [CM] pigweed [CM] apple [D] peru [CM] and such unsightly vegetation [CM] which evidently found something congenial in the soil that had so early borne the black flower of civilized society [CM] a prison [P] But on one side of the portal [CM] and rooted almost at the threshold [CM] was a wild rose [D] bush [CM] covered [CM] in this month of June [CM] with its delicate gems [CM] which might be imagined to offer their fragrance and fragile beauty to the prisoner as he went in [CM] and to the condemned criminal as he came forth to his doom [CM] in token that the deep heart of Nature could pity and be kind to him

1	[PB] So the mother and little Pearl were admitted into the hall of entrance [P] With many variations [CM] suggested by the nature of his building [D] materials [CM] diversity of climate [CM] and a different mode of social life [CM] Governor Bellingham had planned his new habitation after the residences of gentlemen of fair estate in his native land [P] Here [CM] then [CM] was a wide and reasonably lofty hall [CM] extending through the whole depth of the house [CM] and forming a medium of general communication [CM] more or less directly [CM] with all the other apartments [P] At one extremity [CM] this spacious room was lighted by the windows of the two towers [CM] which formed a small recess on either side of the portal [P] At the other end [CM] though partly muffled by a curtain [CM] it was more powerfully illuminated by one of those embowed hall [D] windows which we read of in old books [CM] and which was provided with a deep and cushioned seat [P] Here [CM] on the cushion [CM] lay a folio tome [CM] probably of the Chronicles of England [CM] or other such substantial literature [S] even as [CM] in our own days [CM] we scatter gilded volumes on the centre [D] table [CM] to be turned over by the casual guest [P] The furniture of the hall consisted of some ponderous chairs [CM] the backs of which were elaborately carved with wreaths of oaken flowers [S] and likewise a table in the same taste [S] the whole being of the Elizabethan age [CM] or perhaps earlier [CM] and heirlooms [CM] transferred hither from the Governor s paternal home [P] On the table in token that the sentiment of old English hospitality had not been left behind stood a large pewter tankard [CM] at the bottom of which [CM] had Hester or Pearl peeped into it [CM] they might have seen the frothy remnant of a recent draught of ale [P] [PB] On the wall hung a row of portraits [CM] representing the forefathers of the Bellingham lineage [CM] some with armor on their breasts [CM] and others with stately ruffs and robes of peace [P] All were characterized by the sternness and severity which old portraits so invariably put on

seer [P] Here the pale clergyman piled up his library [CM] rich with parchment [D] bound folios of the Fathers [CM] and the lore of Rabbis [CM] and monkish erudition [CM] of which the Protestant divines [CM] even while they vilified and decried that class of writers [CM] were yet constrained often to avail themselves [P] On the other side of the house old Roger Chillingworth arranged his study and laboratory [S] not such as a modern man of science would reckon even tolerably complete [CM] but provided with a distilling apparatus [CM] and the means of compounding drugs and chemicals familiarly passing from one apartment to the other [CM] and bestowing a mutual and not incurious inspection into one another s business [P] [PB] And the Reverend Arthur Dimmesdale s best discerning friends [CM] as we have intimated [CM] very reasonably imagined that the hand of Providence had done all this [CM] for the purpose besought in so many public [CM] and domestic [CM] and secret prayers 1	Emerson [CM] hitherto fortunately asleep [CM] thanks to a heavy lunch and the drowsy atmosphere of Spring [P] She looked on the expedition as the work of Fate [P] But for it she would have avoided George Emerson successfully [P] In an open manner he had shown that he wished to continue their intimacy [P] She had refused [CM] not because she disliked him [CM] but because she did not know what had happened [CM] and suspected that he did know [P] And this frightened her [P] [PB] For the real event whatever it was had taken place [CM] not in the Loggia [CM] but by the river [P] To behave wildly at the sight of death is pardonable [P] But to discuss it afterwards [CM] to pass from discussion into silence [CM] and through silence into sympathy [CM] that is an error [CM] not of a startled emotion [CM] but of the whole fabric [P] There was really something blameworthy she thought in their joint contemplation of the shadowy stream [CM] in the common impulse which had turned them to the house without the passing of a look or word [P] This sense of wickedness had been slight at first [P] She had nearly joined the party to the Torre del Gallo [P] But each time that she avoided George it became more imperative that she should avoid him again [P] And now celestial irony [CM] working through her cousin and two clergymen [CM] did not suffer her to leave Florence till she had made this expedition with him through the hills [P] [PB] Meanwhile Mr [P] Eager held her in civil converse [S] their little tiff was over [P] [PB] So [CM] Miss Honeychurch [CM] you are travelling [QN] [D] Dame [CM] had any promise on it of healthy life or wholesome aspirations

1	The links that united her to the rest of human kind links of flowers [CM] or silk [CM] or gold [CM] or whatever the material had all been broken [P] Here was the iron link of mutual crime [CM] which neither he nor she could break [P] Like all other ties [CM] it brought along with it its obligations [P] [PB] Hester Prynne did not now occupy precisely the same position in which we beheld her during the earlier periods of her ignominy [P] Years had come and gone [P] Pearl was now seven years old [P] Her mother [CM] with the scarlet letter on her breast [CM] glittering in its fantastic embroidery [CM] had long been a familiar object to the towns [D] people [P] As is apt to be the case when a person stands out in any prominence before the community [CM] and [CM] at the same time [CM] interferes neither with public nor individual interests and convenience [CM] a species of general regard had ultimately grown up in reference to Hester Prynne [P] It is to the credit of human nature [CM] that [CM] except where its selfishness is brought into play [CM] it loves more readily than it hates [P] Hatred [CM] by a gradual and quiet process [CM] will even be transformed to love [CM] unless the change be impeded by a continually new irritation of the original feeling of hostility [P] In this matter of Hester Prynne [CM] there was neither irritation nor irksomeness [P] She never battled with the public [CM] but submitted [CM] uncomplainingly [CM] to its worst usage [S] she made no claim upon it [CM] in requital for what she suffered [S] she did not weigh upon its sympathies [P] Then [CM] also [CM] the blameless purity of her life during all these years in which she had been set apart to infamy [CM] was reckoned largely in her favor [P] With nothing now to lose [CM] in the sight of mankind [CM] and with no hope [CM] and seemingly no wish [CM] of gaining anything [CM] it could only be a genuine regard for virtue that had brought back the poor wanderer to its paths [P] [PB] [P] For her kindred [CM] should the tidings ever reach them [CM] and for the companions of her unspotted life [CM] there remained nothing but the contagion of her dishonor [S] which would not fail to connection with the fallen woman had been the most intimate and sacred of them all [CM] come forward to vindicate his claim to an inheritance so little desirable [QN] He resolved not to be pilloried 1	[PB] Thus Roger Chillingworth scrutinized his patient carefully [CM] both as he saw him in his ordinary life [CM] keeping an accustomed pathway in the range of thoughts familiar to him [CM] and as he appeared when thrown amidst other moral scenery [CM] the novelty of which might call out something new to the surface of his character [P] He deemed it essential [CM] it would seem [CM] to know the man [CM] before attempting to do him good [P] Wherever there is a heart and an intellect [CM] the diseases of the physical frame are tinged with the peculiarities of these [P] In Arthur Dimmesdale [CM] thought and imagination were so active [CM] and sensibility so intense [CM] that the bodily infirmity would be likely to have its groundwork there [P] So Roger Chillingworth the man of skill [CM] the kind and friendly physician strove to go deep into his patient s bosom [CM] delving among his principles [CM] prying into his recollections [CM] and probing everything with a cautious touch [CM] like a treasure [D] seeker in a dark cavern [P] Few secrets can escape an investigator [CM] who has opportunity and license to undertake such a quest [CM] and skill to follow it up [P] A man burdened with a secret should especially avoid the intimacy of his physician [P] If the latter possess native sagacity [CM] and a nameless something more [CM] let us call it intuition [S] if he show no intrusive egotism [CM] nor disagreeably prominent characteristics of his own [S] if he have the power [CM] which must be born with him [CM] to bring his mind into such affinity with his patient s [CM] that this last shall unawares have spoken what he imagines himself only to have thought [S] if such revelations be received without tumult [CM] and acknowledged not so often by an uttered sympathy as by silence [CM] an inarticulate breath [CM] and here and there a word [CM] to indicate that all is understood [S] if to these qualifications of a confidant be joined the advantages afforded by his recognized character as a physician [S] then [CM] at some inevitable moment [CM] will the soul of the sufferer be dissolved [CM] and flow forth in a dark [CM] but transparent stream [CM] bringing all its mysteries into the daylight

1	No longer ago than yester [D] eve [CM] a magistrate [CM] a wise and godly man [CM] was discoursing of your affairs [CM] Mistress Hester [CM] and whispered me that there had been question concerning you in the council [P] It was debated whether or no [CM] with safety to the common weal [CM] yonder scarlet letter might be taken off your bosom [P] On my life [CM] Hester [CM] I made my entreaty to the worshipful magistrate that it might be done forthwith [E] [PB] It lies not in the pleasure of the magistrates to take off this badge [CM] calmly replied Hester [P] Were I worthy to be quit of it [CM] it would fall away of its own nature [CM] or be transformed into something that should speak a different purport [P] [PB] Nay [CM] then [CM] wear it [CM] if it suit you better [CM] rejoined he [P] A woman must needs follow her own fancy [CM] touching the adornment of her person [P] The letter is gayly embroidered [CM] and shows right bravely on your bosom [E] [PB] All this while [CM] Hester had been looking steadily at the old man [CM] and was shocked [CM] as well as wonder [D] smitten [CM] to discern what a change had been wrought upon him within the past seven years [P] It was not so much that he had grown older [S] for though the traces of advancing life were visible [CM] he bore his age well [CM] and seemed to retain a wiry vigor and alertness [P] But the former aspect of an intellectual and studious man [CM] calm and quiet [CM] which was what she best remembered in him [CM] had altogether vanished [CM] and been succeeded by an eager [CM] searching [CM] almost fierce [CM] yet carefully guarded look [P] It seemed to be his wish and purpose to mask this expression with a smile [S] but the latter played him false [CM] and flickered over his visage so derisively [CM] that the spectator could see his blackness all the better for it [P] Ever and anon [CM] too [CM] there came a glare of red light out of his eyes [S] as if the old man s soul were on fire [CM] and kept on 1	Lydgate s conceit was of the arrogant sort [CM] never simpering [CM] never impertinent [CM] but massive in its claims and benevolently contemptuous [P] He would do a great deal for noodles [CM] being sorry for them [CM] and feeling quite sure that they could have no power over him [CN] he had thought of joining the Saint Simonians when he was in Paris [CM] in order to turn them against some of their own doctrines [P] All his faults were marked by kindred traits [CM] and were those of a man who had a fine baritone [CM] whose clothes hung well upon him [CM] and who even in his ordinary gestures had an air of inbred distinction [P] Where then lay the spots of commonness [QN] says a young lady enamoured of that careless grace [P] How could there be any commonness in a man so well [D] bred [CM] so ambitious of social distinction [CM] so generous and unusual in his views of social duty [QN] As easily as there may be stupidity in a man of genius if you take him unawares on the wrong subject [CM] or as many a man who has the best will to advance the social millennium might be ill [D] inspired in imagining its lighter pleasures [S] unable to go beyond Offenbach s music [CM] or the brilliant punning in the last burlesque [P] Lydgate s spots of commonness lay in the complexion of his prejudices [CM] which [CM] in spite of noble intention and sympathy [CM] were half of them such as are found in ordinary men of the world [CN] that distinction of mind which belonged to his intellectual ardor [CM] did not penetrate his feeling and judgment about furniture [CM] or women [CM] or the desirability of its being known without his telling that he was better born than other country surgeons [P] He did not mean to think of furniture at present [S] but whenever he did so it was to be he had once already been drawn headlong by impetuous folly [CM] which he meant to be final [CM] since marriage at some distant period would of course not be impetuous

dishonourable to the stability of her lover [CM] she could not prevent its frequently recurring [P] The united efforts of his two unfeeling sisters [CM] and of his overpowering friend [CM] assisted by the attractions of Miss Darcy and the amusements of London [CM] might be too much [CM] she feared [CM] for the strength of his attachment [P] [PB] As for Jane [CM] her anxiety under this suspense was [CM] of course [CM] more painful than Elizabeth s [CN] but whatever she felt she was desirous of concealing [S] and between herself and Elizabeth [CM] therefore [CM] the subject was never alluded to if he did not come back she should think herself very ill [D] used [P] It needed all Jane s steady mildness to bear these attacks with tolerable tranquillity [P] [PB] Mr [P] Collins returned most punctually on the Monday fortnight [CM] but his reception at Longbourn was not quite so gracious as it had been on his first introduction [P] He was too happy [CM] however [CM] to need much attention [S] and [CM] luckily for the others [CM] the business of love [D] making relieved them from a great deal of his company [P] The chief of every day was spent by him at Lucas Lodge [CM] and he sometimes that house [CM] she regarded her with jealous abhorrence

1	corner was the sunny part of his life [P] [PB] On this certain fine Sunday [CM] Mr [P] Lorry walked towards Soho [CM] early in the afternoon [CM] for three reasons of habit [P] Firstly [CM] because [CM] on fine Sundays [CM] he often walked out [CM] before dinner [CM] with the Doctor and Lucie [S] secondly [CM] because [CM] on unfavourable Sundays [CM] he was accustomed to be with them as the family friend [CM] talking [CM] reading [CM] looking out of window [CM] and generally getting through the day [S] thirdly [CM] because he happened to have his own little shrewd doubts to solve [CM] and knew how the ways of the Doctor s household pointed to that time as a likely time for solving them [P] [PB] A quainter corner than the corner where the Doctor lived [CM] was not to be found in London [P] There was no way through it [CM] and the front windows of the Doctor s lodgings commanded a pleasant little vista of street that had a congenial air of retirement on it [P] There were few buildings then [CM] north of the Oxford [D] road [CM] and forest [D] trees flourished [CM] and wild flowers grew [CM] and the hawthorn blossomed [CM] in the now vanished fields [P] As a consequence [CM] country airs circulated in Soho with vigorous freedom [CM] instead of languishing into the parish like stray paupers without a settlement [S] and there was many a good south wall [CM] not far off [CM] on which the peaches ripened in their season [P] [PB] The summer light struck into the corner brilliantly in the earlier part of the day [S] but [CM] when the streets grew hot [CM] the corner was in shadow [CM] though not in shadow so remote but that you could see beyond it into a glare of brightness [P] It was a cool spot [CM] staid but cheerful [CM] a wonderful place for echoes [CM] and a very harbour from the raging streets [P] [PB] There ought to have been a tranquil bark in such an anchorage [CM] and there was [P] The Doctor occupied two floors of a large stiff house [CM] where several callings purported to be pursued by day [CM] but whereof little was audible any day [CM] and which was shunned by all of them at night

1	She was at times almost afraid to let herself think these thoughts [P] They were so vivid that she felt as if the others must know what she was thinking [P] [PB] I ve been watching a woodpecker all day [CM] he said one evening on the shaky old back verandah [P] His account of the woodpecker s doings was satisfying [P] He had often some gay or cunning little anecdote of the wood folk to tell them [P] And sometimes he and Roaring Abel smoked fiercely the whole evening and never said a word [CM] while Cissy lay in the hammock swung between the verandah posts and Valancy sat idly on the steps [CM] her hands clasped over her knees [CM] and wondered dreamily if she were really Valancy Stirling and if it were only three weeks since she had left the ugly old house on Elm Street [P] [PB] The barrens lay before her in a white moon splendour [CM] where dozens of little rabbits frisked [P] Barney [CM] when he liked [CM] could sit down on the edge of the barrens and lure those rabbits right to him by some mysterious sorcery he possessed [P] Valancy had once seen a squirrel leap from a scrub pine to his shoulder and sit there chattering to him [P] It reminded her of John Foster [P] [PB] It was one of the delights of Valancy s new life that she could read John Foster s books as often and as long as she liked [P] She could read them in bed if she wanted to [P] She read them all to Cissy [CM] who loved them [P] She also tried to read them to Abel and Barney [CM] who did not love them [P] Abel was bored and Barney politely refused to listen at all [P] [PB] Piffle [CM] said Barney [P] [PB] CHAPTER XIX [PB] Of course [CM] the Stirlings had not left the poor maniac alone all this time or refrained from heroic efforts to rescue her perishing soul and reputation [P] Uncle James [CM] whose lawyer had helped him as little as his doctor [CM] came one day and [CM] finding Valancy alone in the kitchen [CM] as he supposed [CM] gave her a terrible talking

1	It was accepted [S] and from that period Jane had belonged to Colonel Campbell s family [CM] and had lived with them entirely [CM] only visiting her grandmother from time to time [P] [PB] The plan was that she should be brought up for educating others [S] the very few hundred pounds which she inherited from her father making independence impossible [P] To provide for her otherwise was out of Colonel Campbell s power [S] for though his income [CM] by pay and appointments [CM] was handsome [CM] his fortune was moderate and must be all his daughter s [S] but [CM] by giving her an education [CM] he hoped to be supplying the means of respectable subsistence hereafter [P] [PB] Such was Jane Fairfax s history [P] She had fallen into good hands [CM] known nothing but kindness from the Campbells [CM] and been given an excellent education [P] Living constantly with right [D] minded and well [D] informed people [CM] her heart and understanding had received every advantage of discipline and culture [S] and Colonel Campbell s residence being in London [CM] every lighter talent had been done full justice to [CM] by the attendance of first [D] rate masters [P] Her disposition and abilities were equally worthy of all that friendship could do [S] and at eighteen or nineteen she was [CM] as far as such an early age can be qualified for the care of children [CM] fully competent to the office of instruction herself [S] but she was too much beloved to be parted with [P] Neither father nor mother could promote [CM] and the daughter could not endure it [P] The evil day was put off [P] It was easy to decide that she was still too young [S] and Jane remained with them [CM] sharing [CM] as another daughter [CM] in all the rational pleasures of an elegant society [CM] and a judicious mixture of home and amusement [CM] with only the drawback of the future [CM] the sobering suggestions of her own good understanding to remind her that all this might soon be over [P] [PB] The affection of the whole family [CM] the warm attachment of Miss Campbell in particular [CM] was the more honourable to each party from the circumstance of Jane s decided superiority both in beauty and acquirements

1	Casaubon s learning as mere accomplishment [S] for though opinion in the neighborhood of Freshitt and Tipton had pronounced her clever [CM] that epithet would not have described her to circles in whose more precise vocabulary cleverness implies mere aptitude for knowing and doing [CM] apart from character [P] All her eagerness for acquirement lay within that full current of sympathetic motive herself for the sentiment [CM] but could not overcome or lessen it [P] Attempting to do so [CM] she thought of those long [D] past days [CM] in a distant land [CM] when he used to emerge at eventide from the seclusion of his study [CM] and sit down in the firelight of their home [CM] and in the light of her nuptial smile [P] He needed to bask himself in that smile [CM] he said [CM] in order that the chill of so many lonely hours among his books might be taken off the scholar s heart [P] Such scenes had once appeared not otherwise than happy [CM] but now [CM] as viewed through the dismal medium of her subsequent life [CM] they classed themselves among her ugliest remembrances [P] She marvelled how such scenes could have been [E] She marvelled how she could ever have been wrought upon to marry him [E] She deemed it her crime most to be repented of [CM] that she had ever endured [CM] and reciprocated [CM] the lukewarm grasp of his hand [CM] and had suffered the smile of her lips and eyes to mingle and melt into his own [P] And it seemed a fouler offence committed by Roger Chillingworth [CM] than any which had since been done him [CM] that [CM] in the time when her heart knew no better [CM] he had persuaded her to fancy herself happy by his side [P] [PB] Yes [CM] I hate him [E] repeated Hester [CM] more bitterly than before [P] He betrayed me [E] He has done me worse wrong than I did him [E] [PB] Let men tremble to win the hand of woman [CM] unless they win along with it the utmost passion of her heart [E] Else it may be their miserable fortune [CM] as it was Roger will have imposed upon her as the warm reality

1	She dearly loved her father [CM] but he was no companion for her [P] He could not meet her in conversation [CM] rational or playful [P] [PB] The evil of the actual disparity in their ages and Mr [P] Woodhouse had not married early was much increased by his constitution and habits [S] for having been a valetudinarian all his life [CM] without activity of mind or body [CM] he was a much older man in ways than in years [S] and though everywhere beloved for the friendliness of his heart and his amiable temper [CM] his talents could not have recommended him at any time [P] [PB] Her sister [CM] though comparatively but little removed by matrimony [CM] being settled in London [CM] only sixteen miles off [CM] was much beyond her daily reach [S] and many a long October and November evening must be struggled through at Hartfield [CM] before Christmas brought the next visit from Isabella and her husband [CM] and their little children [CM] to fill the house [CM] and give her pleasant society again [P] [PB] Highbury [CM] the large and populous village [CM] almost amounting to a town [CM] to which Hartfield [CM] in spite of its separate lawn [CM] and shrubberies [CM] and name [CM] did really belong [CM] afforded her no equals [P] The Woodhouses were first in consequence there [P] All looked up to them [P] She had many acquaintance in the place [CM] for her father was universally civil [CM] but not one among them who could be accepted in lieu of Miss Taylor for even half a day [P] It was a melancholy change [S] and Emma could not but sigh over it [CM] and wish for impossible things [CM] till her father awoke [CM] and made it necessary to be cheerful [P] His spirits required support [P] He was a nervous man [CM] easily depressed [S] fond of every body that he was used to
